header_summary: Emails from Ethan Heilman, Peter Todd, Fabian, and ZmnSCPxj cover opcode limitations in tapscript, a proposed solution to prevent attacks on the Lightning Network, considerations for unexplored options in a proposal, and details of a core attack on the network involving nodes A, B, and C. Ethan clarifies the limit in tapscript, Peter discusses the limitations of the proposed solution, Fabian suggests exploring an unconsidered option, and ZmnSCPxj explains a step-by-step attack scenario.

recent_posts.title: Proposed BIP for OP_CAT
recent_posts.summary:
- The tapscript opcode enforces a 520 byte element size, preventing large stack elements.
- The limit on tapscript is not unique and relates to the removal of OP_CAT opcode.
- Ethan expresses gratitude to Greg for pointing out the limit and other changes.

recent_posts.title: OP_Expire and Coinbase-Like Behavior: Making HTLCs Safer by Letting Transactions Expire Safely
recent_posts.summary:
- The proposed solution does not effectively address a specific attack involving replacement cycling.
- Implementation of the "anyone-can-spend" branch allows multiple individuals, including miners, to perform the attack.
- The solution is considered inferior to OP_Expire due to strict deadlines and lack of flexibility.

recent_posts.title: Breaking change in calculation of hash_serialized_2
recent_posts.summary:
- The email suggests considering an option not previously discussed in the proposal.
- Reasons for not considering this option could be the effectiveness of the existing hash.
- Further optimization and alternative strategies for peer-to-peer sharing are mentioned as well.

recent_posts.title: Full Disclosure: CVE-2023-40231 / CVE-2023-40232 / CVE-2023-40233 / CVE-2023-40234 "All your	mempool are belong to us"
recent_posts.summary:
- ZmnSCPxj explains a core attack on the Lightning Network, involving nodes A, B, and C.
- The attack exploits expired timelocks and the ability to change feerates for transactions.
- Node C has an advantage in feebumping transactions, making it easier to claim the value of HTLCs.

active_posts.title: Full Disclosure: CVE-2023-40231 / CVE-2023-40232 / CVE-2023-40233 / CVE-2023-40234 "All your mempool are belong to us"
active_posts.summary:
- A new attack called replacement cycling targets lightning channels, posing a threat of fund loss.
- Major lightning implementations such as LDK, Eclair, LND, and Core-Lightning have implemented mitigations.
- The attack involves replacing HTLC-timeout transactions, but no attacks have been observed yet.

active_posts.title: Batch exchange withdrawal to lightning requires covenants
active_posts.summary:
- The email discusses the design of a protocol for lightning wallet withdrawals from exchanges.
- The current method burdens the user's wallet provider and sometimes requires splice transactions.
- The proposed solution is to batch transactions and use `SIGHASH_ANYPREVOUT` to address signatures and security.

active_posts.title: BitVM: Compute Anything on Bitcoin
active_posts.summary:
- BitVM is a computing paradigm for Turing-complete Bitcoin contracts without changing consensus rules.
- Computations are verified, akin to optimistic rollups, by making claims with fraud proofs.
- Off-chain collaboration allows complex computation without on-chain footprint, with on-chain execution for disputes.

active_posts.title: Full Disclosure: CVE-2023-40231 / CVE-2023-40232 / CVE-2023-40233 / CVE-2023-40234 "All your mempool are belong to us"
active_posts.summary:
- A new attack called the replacement cycling attack poses a risk to lightning channels.
- Major lightning implementations have implemented mitigations against this attack.
- Bitcoin applications using timelocks or multi-party transactions could also be affected.

active_posts.title: Batch exchange withdrawal to lightning requires covenants
active_posts.summary:
- The sender proposes using `SIGHASH_ANYPREVOUT` covenants to enable lightning withdrawals from exchanges.
- The current method of lightning withdrawals shifts the burden to the user's wallet provider.
- Batching transactions into a single transaction can be a solution but introduces other challenges.

active_posts.title: Removing channel reserve for mobile wallet users
active_posts.summary:
- The email discusses removing channel reserve requirements for channels between mobile wallet users and service providers.
- The author highlights drawbacks, including capital efficiency and user experience, and argues for removal.
- Removing the reserve allows service providers to pay on-chain fees and grief users if they cheat.
